title: Male Breast Mass - Gynecomastia vs Carcinoma
setup_script: A 60-year-old man notices a painless lump under his right nipple. He is overweight, takes spironolactone for heart failure, and has no family history of breast cancer. On exam, there is a 2 cm firm subareolar mass.

dynamic_flow.trigger: Gather history including duration of mass, medication use (spironolactone, estrogen), liver disease, and testicular symptoms.
Perform thorough breast and testicular exams; assess for lymphadenopathy.
Order bilateral diagnostic mammography and ultrasound to differentiate gynecomastia (diffuse subareolar density) from suspicious mass.
If imaging shows suspicious features, perform core needle biopsy to rule out carcinoma.
Review biopsy results: if gynecomastia, consider medication review, treat underlying cause; if carcinoma, stage accordingly.
Discuss risk factors for male breast cancer including BRCA mutations, Klinefelter syndrome, and radiation exposure; offer genetic testing if indicated.
If carcinoma diagnosed, plan modified radical mastectomy due to small breast size; discuss sentinel lymph node biopsy.
Obtain informed consent; explain surgical risks and need for adjuvant therapy (chemotherapy, endocrine therapy depending on receptor status).
Perform surgery; orient specimen; send sentinel nodes for frozen section; proceed to axillary dissection if positive.
Postoperative management: manage drain, wound, and discuss radiation therapy if large tumor or nodal involvement.
Refer patient to medical oncology for systemic therapy; coordinate endocrine therapy (tamoxifen) for hormone receptor positive disease.
Provide counseling on body image, support groups, and monitoring for recurrence.

critical_decision_points: Distinguishing gynecomastia from carcinoma with appropriate imaging and biopsy.
Recognizing risk factors and indications for genetic testing in male breast cancer.
Selecting appropriate surgical management and sentinel lymph node biopsy.
Coordinating adjuvant therapy based on receptor status.
Addressing psychosocial aspects and survivorship in male patients.
